Title:
Molecular analyses uncover the phylogenetic placement of the
lichenized hyphomycetous genus Cheiromycina
Keywords:
cheiroid conidia, Lecanorales, Malmideaceae, mycobiont,
ribosomal DNA, symbiosis
Abstract:
The genus Cheiromycina represents one of few genera of
lichenized hyphomycetes for which no sexual reproductive stages are
known. The genus includes species growing on bark or wood which have
been described from boreal to temperate regions of the Northern
Hemisphere. Cheiromycina is characterized by a non-corticated thallus
containing chlorococcoid photobionts, nearly immersed in the bark or
wood and presenting powdery unpigmented sporodochia. In the type species
C. flabelliformis, in C. petri and in C. reimeri the multicellular
conidia are peculiarly cheiroid, dichotomously branched. Here we
explored the phylogenetic placement of Cheiromycina as its relationships
with other fungi were still unknown. The three mentioned species coming
from different localities were successfully sequenced for three loci
(nuSSU, nuLSU and mtSSU). The genus Cheiromycina is found within
Lecanorales in the family Malmideaceae forming a monophyletic clade
sister to the genera Savoronala and Malmidea; this phylogenetic
placement and the relationships of Cheiromycina with other lichenized
hyphomycetous taxa is here discussed.
